3.3 The phenomena of dreams and only possible basis of skepticism

The phenomena of dreams are thought to pose an objection to belief in
the existence of the external world because we may credit the illusory
images with continued, external, independent existence. This is reason
to doubt the existence of all perceptual objects unless we have better
evidence for their reality than we have for that of the seeming
objects of dreams. Shepherd dispatches the objection. She grants that
sensations that occur in dreams are like those that occur in waking
experience although she denies that dreams can cause the same
sensations in the same order as those caused by objects existing in
nature (EPEU [2020: 99–100]). She argues that when dreaming, a
person’s ability to collect a large number of sensations is
limited. When awake, we can move our eyes and limbs and find the
supposed object does not fulfill its definition (e.g. EPEU [2020:
29–33]). She allows that assuming we are awake, it is difficult
to know whether an object that has fulfilled its presumed definition
so far will do so later on. Judgments on this question can be
supported by observations that make them more or less probable and
thus subject to an appropriate level of doubt (ERCE [2020:
99–114]). Still, she admits there is one (but only one) possible
basis for skepticism about the reality of perceptual objects:
experience cannot show that the causes of all a person’s
sensations are not necessarily mixed with the causes of her dreams
(EPEU [2020: 118–19]).
